_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies:
Our company is committed to protecting the environment and operating facilities in a manner that promotes the safety of employees and the general public. At this facility, we store and handle liquefied petroleum gases. The management as adopted and implemented policies and procedures that adhere to all applicable Federal and state rules and regulations. The most current edition of NFPA 58 is followed for the safe handling of liquefied petroleum gases and the maintenance of equipment. Safety is the number one consideration in the handling of liquefied petroleum gases, the design and maintenance of the equipment, and the training of our personnel. The Certified Employee Training program (CETP) modules relating to Railcar product transfer is the guide for safety practices and procedures at this facility.

Our emergency response plan is based upon the Guidelines for Developing Plant Emergency Procedures and How to Control L-P Gas Leaks and Fires. Facility staff will not respond to accidental releases of flammable substances at our facility, but has coordinated response actions with the local fire department. Our response plan includes procedures to call the local emergency responders as well as any potential affected neighbors. 

Stationary source and regulated substance handled:
The regulated substance handled at this facility is liquefied petroleum gases. The purpose of this facility is to store liquefied petroleum gases for distribution to wholesale customers. The liquefied petroleum gases are received by rail car, up to 100 rail cars. This facility is equipped to unload railcars into transport trucks to be hauled to wholesale customers. This facility does not sell liquefied petroleum gases to the general public. The transfer equipment has been designed and built according to the provisions of NFPA 58. Federal department of transportation inspectors periodically inspect the

facility. 

General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps:
This facility complies with all Federal and state rules and regulations that govern the storage, handling, and transportation of liquefied petroleum gases. It also complies with the including OSAH PSM rule and EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule. The transfer equipment was designed in accordance with NFPA 58 code for the storage and handling of liquefied petroleum gases. Period inspections of the transfer equipment are done to ensure continued safe operations. All maintenance and improvements are done per the latest NFPA code in effect at that time. To ensure that it is operated and maintained properly, regulatory authorities inspect this facility. The employees are trained as required by the appropriate codes and regulations using the Certified Employee Training Program (CETP).

Five-year accident history:
No accidental releases of liquefied petroleum gases have occurred at this facility resulting in off-site consequences.

Emergency Response program:
The emergency response plan at this facility was based upon the NPGA bulletins Guidelines for Developing Plant Emergency Procedures and How to Control Small Leaks and Fires and the CETP training program. Employees are trained in emergency operating procedures such as controlling sources of ignition and leaks. Employees are not trained in emergency medical response and are not equipped to respond to offsite releases. Facility employees will not respond to accidental releases of a regulated flammable substance. Emergency response will be coordinated with the local fire authorities. The plan identifies who is responsible for calling emergency responders and notifying potentially affected neighbors.

Planned changes to improve safety:
The facility was opened in 2017 to meet or exceed all existing standards and is maintained in compliance with NFPA 58. The staff has been trained using the Certified Employe

e Training Program developed by the National Propane Gas Association in addition to industry safety practices and procedures. Safety practices are continually reviewed. Equipment and maintenance programs are monitored on an ongoing basis.
